doc.title: Eiffage: Political turmoil overshadows earnings release

passages.text: SOCIETE GENERALE GROUP
**Specialist Sales**

**1H results reported yesterday - highlights.** 1) Group EBIT came to c.£1bn (+0.9% yoy),slightly below our estimate and the consensus forecast. 2) Net profit was £308m (-19.4%yoy), above our forecast and street expectations, due to lower taxes and minorities. 3) FCF was -£91m (vs £148m in 1H24, and vs our estimate of £100m). FCF was lower due to higher seasonal WC outflows of £892m in 1H25 (vs £672m in 1H24, and vs our estimate of £750m). 4) Eiffage ended 1H25 with net debt of £9.9bn (£9.4bn as of end-Dec 2024),reflecting DPS payments and the slightly negative FCF due to the seasonal effect. 5) The Contracting backlog was robust at £29.5bn (+2% ytd; -0.7% vs 1Q25).

**Divisional 1H25 EBIT margins.** Contracting: Construction delivered an operating margin of 3.4% (3.4% in 1H24; 3.6% in FY24; 3.7% in FY23; FY25e 3.6%). At the Infrastructure division, the EBIT margin was -0.2% (1H24 -0.3%, FY24 3.3%, FY23 3.2%; FY25e 3.4%).Lastly, the Energy Systems division posted an EBIT margin of 4.9% (1H24 4.6%, FY24 5.8%,FY23 5.4%; FY25e 6%). Concessions: the division's EBIT margin was 44.2% (1H24 44.3%,FY24 43%, 46.3% in FY23; FY25e 43.1%).

**FY25 outlook reiterated.** Eiffage reaffirmed (link) that it expects an increase in revenue and operating profit on ordinary activities in Concessions and Contracting. Regarding the bottom line, Eiffage is aiming for an "increase in net profit Group share at a constant rate of taxation, [but] down because of the exceptional corporation tax contribution in France in 2025". Our current FY25 group net profit estimate of £959m (Bloomberg consensus: c.£980m) assumes a c.8% annual decline in the reported figure due to the tax impact.

**Conf. call feedback.** 1) There was no specific guidance on FY25 WC; however, management mentioned that a prudent release of cash could be expected. 2) Management highlighted the solid position in Germany, to capture potential future growth derived from new Infra plan. That said, new projects will take time to materialise. 3) The more negative 1H holding EBIT reflected the increase in the share-based payment expense following the sharp rise in Eiffage's share price. 4) On strategy regarding the GET stake, there was no change to prior statements. 5) Management expressed confidence that Energy division would reach sales of c.8bn and an EBIT margin of c.6% in FY25. 6) APRR's traffic generated slight growth in the summer (July-Aug.); no specific FY25 APRR traffic target was provided.
Next event. Domestic political picture (Bayrou; vote of confidence on 8 September).

EXHIBIT 4: Eiffage - 1H contracting backlog (€bn)

Bemstein view. The 1H results published yesterday after market close were mixed, combining a beat on NP but a slight miss at EBIT level on higher holding costs (see Exhibit 2). The slightly negative 1H FCF was explained by larger WC outflows and increased growth in investment in Concessions (new infra projects). In our view, the short- term focus remains on the domestic political uncertainty (Bayrou, vote of confidence on 8 September) on which visibility remains very limited at this stage. In last few trading days, French stocks have been under pressure as renewed political uncertainty is weighing on investor sentiment. For the second consecutive year, late August has brought turbulence to Paris, with looming budget negotiations once again highlighting the differences between the various blocs. On Monday, Prime Minister Mr Bayrou unexpectedly announced a vote of confidence for early September, raising fears that the government could collapse if it fails to secure parliamentary backing (central scenario). We do not see the 1H results driving a significant change in Street consensus' annual estimates. We have an Outperform rating on the stock with a €158.9 PT. For our investment case, see our report of 18 Mar 2025 - Eiffage: We still see a substantial value gap.

References to "Bernstein" or the "Firm" in these disclosures relate to the following entities: Bernstein Institutional Services LLC (April 1, 2024 onwards), Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., LLC (pre April 1, 2024), Bernstein Autonomous LLP, BSG France S.A. (April 1, 2024 onwards), Sanford C. Bernstein (Hong Kong) Limited 盛博香港有限公司, Sanford C. Bernstein (Canada) Limited, Sanford C. Bernstein (India) Private Limited (SEBI registration no. INH000006378), Sanford C. Bernstein (Singapore) Private Limited and Sanford C. Bernstein Japan KK (サンフォード・C・バーンスタイン株式会社).

On April 1, 2024, Société Générale (SG) and AllianceBernstein, LP. (AB) completed a transaction that created a new joint venture in which their respective cash equities and research businesses operate in a new business combination. Although their respective ownership percentages in the joint venture differ between North America and the rest of the world, the creation, production and publication of research is handled collaboratively on a global basis across the two research brands, "Bernstein" and "Autonomous". Unless specifically noted otherwise, for purposes of these disclosures, references to Bernstein's "affiliates" relate to both SG and AB and their respective affiliates.

We value Eiffage (€158.9 PT) using a SOTP methodology. We use a finite (no terminal value) DCF model (5.4% WACC) to value Eiffage's 52.5% stake in toll road operator APRR, which comprises c.24% of our SOTP- based target price. The rest of the assets (which include other concessions, the 20.55% stake in GET and contracting) are valued using different methodologies (e.g. EV/ EBITDA; target prices, equity invested multiples, DCF, transaction deals). Concessions account for c.49% of our SOTP valuation, while the rest of the assets (mainly contracting) account for 51%.

Downside risks. 1) deterioration in credit markets and increases in real bond yields; 2) units' operational performance far below expectations; 3) M&A deals executed at high prices; and 4) new unexpected higher domestic taxes.

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp- Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp- Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. As our benchmarks we use the Bloomberg Europe 500 Banks And Financial Services Index (BEBANKS) and Bloomberg Europe Dev Mkt Financials Large and Mid Cap Price Ret Index EUR (EDMFI) index for developed European banks and Payments, the Bloomberg Europe 500 Insurance Index (BEINSUR) for European insurers, the S&P 500 and S&P Financials for US banks and Payments coverage, S5LIFE for US Insurance, the S&P Insurance Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non- Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:

Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 pp- Neutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within \(+ / - 10\) pp- Underperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12- month time horizon.
